anchor.surface_text: Misprinting of the name of respondent No. 1 on the ballot papers amounts to number-compliance with r. 22 of the Rules but the proof of such number-compliance does number necessarily or automatically render the election of the appellant void. To make the said election void, respondent No. 1 has to prove the number-compliance in question, and its material effect on the election.

holdings.text: Misprinting of the name of respondent No. 1 on the ballot papers amounts to non-compliance with r. 22 of the Rules but the proof of such non-compliance does not necessarily or automatically render the election of the appellant void. To make the said election void, respondent No. 1 has to prove the non-compliance in question, and its material effect on the election. This latter fact he has failed to prove, and so, his challenge to the validity of the appellants election cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: Misprinting of the name of respondent No. 1 on the ballot papers amounts to non-compliance with r. 22 of the Rules but the proof of such non-compliance does not necessarily or automatically render the election of the appellant void. To make the said election void, respondent No. 1 has to prove the non-compliance in question, and its material effect on the election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Although misprint is non-compliance, s.100(1)(d)(iv) requires proof of material effect on result concerning returned candidate; respondent received substantial votes despite misprint, focusing on correct symbol; no evidence of impact.

holdings.text: On these facts, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in holding that r. 56 2 g had not been contravened.

anchor.surface_text: The symbol chosen by respondent No. 1 was correctly shown on the ballot papers, though his name had been misprinted. On these facts, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in holding that r. 5 6  2   g  had not been contravened.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.56(2)(g) applies to serial number or design (form, pattern, outline) of ballot paper, not contents like candidate's name; symbol was correctly printed.

holdings.text: The design to which r. 56 2 g refers, is the form, the pattern, or the outline of the ballot paper and not the contents of the ballot paper.

anchor.surface_text: The design to which r. 56 2 g refers, is the form, the pattern, or the outline of the ballot paper and number the companytents of the ballot paper. The symbol chosen by respondent No. 1 was companyrectly shown on the ballot papers, though his name had been misprinted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'design' in rule distinguishes structural form from printed contents; misprint affects name, not design.

holdings.text: if it is shown that at any election, any nomination paper has been improperly rejected, the improper rejection itself renders the election void without any further proof about the material effect of this improper rejection.

anchor.surface_text: Likewise, cl.  c  provides that the election of a returned candidate shall be declared void if it is shown that any nomination has been improperly rejected. It would thus be seen that the view which the Election Tribunals and the Courts had been consistently taking [...] now, the position is that if it is shown that at any election, any nomination paper has been improperly rejected, the improper rejection itself renders the election void without any further proof about the material effect of this improper rejection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-1956 amendment confirms judicial view by separating improper rejection under s.100(1)(c) (automatic voiding) from other non-compliances under s.100(1)(d)(iv) requiring material effect proof.

holdings.text: This part of the statutory requirement has not been properly appreciated by the High Court as well as by the Election Tribunal when they came to the conclusion that the election of the appellant had been rendered void under s. 100 1 d iv of the Act by reason of the fact that the name of respondent No. 1 had been misprinted on the ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there can be no doubt that in dealing with the contention raised by respondent No. 1, we will have to enquire whether it has been shown by respondent No. 1 that by reason of the infirmity in the ballot papers, the result of the election has been materially affected. This part of the statutory requirement has not been properly appreciated by the High Court as well as by the Election Tribunal

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.100(1)(d)(iv) mandates enquiry into material effect; lower courts declared void without such proof.

holdings.text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 is dismissed.

precedents.citation: Surendra Nath Khosla and Anr. v. S. Dalip Singh and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Surendra Nath Khosla and Anr. v. S. Dalip Singh and others 1 . On the other hand, in regard to the category of cases where the infirmity was improper acceptance of a numberination paper, different companysiderations had to be taken into account.

precedents.case_name: Surendra Nath Khosla and Anr. v. S. Dalip Singh and others
precedents.cited_proposition: the fact that one of the several candidates had been kept out of the arena is itself a substantial and material consideration which may justify the presumption that such a keeping out the candidate has materially affected the result of the election
precedents.cited_holding: material effect of improper rejection presumed without evidence

precedents.citation: Vashist Narain Sharma v. Dev Chand Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Vashist Narain Sharma v. Dev Chand Others 1 , it was held by this Court that in the case of improper acceptance of a numberination  a  if the numberination accepted was that of the returned candidate, the result must be materially affected  b  if the difference between the number of votes is more than the wasted votes, the result cannot be affected at all  c  if the number of wasted votes is greater than the margin of votes between the returned candidate and the candidate securing the next highest number of votes, it cannot be presumed that the wasted votes might have gone to the latter and that the result of the election has been materially affected.

precedents.case_name: Vashist Narain Sharma v. Dev Chand Others
precedents.cited_proposition: in cases of improper acceptance of nomination paper, material effect on election result must be proved; specific rules for presumption based on vote margins and wasted votes
precedents.cited_holding: (a) if the nomination accepted was that of the returned candidate, the result must be materially affected (b) if the difference between the number of votes is more than the wasted votes, the result cannot be affected at all (c) if the number of wasted votes is greater than the margin of votes between the returned candidate and the candidate securing the next highest number of votes, it cannot be presumed that the wasted votes might have gone to the latter
